section.title: Tying it All Together
section.para: In summary, there are five steps to creating a successful distribution.

First, you configure the SystemBuilder build machine to accommodate the size and number of distributions you will build and store concurrently for download at any single time. The system should be accessible through your local network. After configuring the hardware, you can install one of the Linux OS versions on which SystemBuilder runs.
Then you define your distribution in the samber-server.xml file using XML tags defined in the DDFR. Your definition includes several key pieces of information:

listitem.para: the name of the distribution, its version and architecture;
the repositories for the OS and application packages, including base install and update mirror locations;
the standard package groups for any applications to include and any packages to exclude; and
custom system configuration files and required packages outside the standard application groups.

section.para: Once the distribution definition is complete, you log on as the root user and execute the command systembuilder samber-server.xml to build the distribution. Output goes to the screen and the default log file. The first build may take some time, since SystemBuilder needs to do everything the first time:

validate the samber-server.xml file,
locate active repositories,
resolve package dependencies,
retrieve the necessary packages,
retrieve other configuration or user-provided files,
create the config.rpm and release.rpm files,
create the boot.iso and other required images, and
store the distribution on the download server.
Deploying client machines requires three steps. First, SystemBuilder will publish the distribution image files to the download server location from which the client system will obtain its initial installation and subsequent updates. By default, the location will be in the web server area on the SystemBuilder build machine. Second, you create the CD or DVD boot media. Lastly, you install the client machine by inserting the disk into the client machine and later verifying that the contents are correct.

Updating your distribution, the final step, can involve simply checking for mirror repository updates. Depending upon the changes SystemBuilder encounters, systembuilder could update the distribution with updated packages. After updating the distribution, you will need to run yum update on the client machine to keep the client in synch with the current distribution.

Another method to update your distribution is actually changing the definition, samber-server.xml for this scenario. Any changes to the three required main child elements would constitute creating a brand-new distribution. Save these changes to a new filename.

In the Samba CentOS 5 Server example presented here, what you have in the end is a distribution for a Samba server on CentOS 5 for the i386 architecture. It includes GUI applications as well as a web server, administration and printing capabilities. Your custom smb.conf file provides custom Samba configuration instructions. The packages come from the repositories at http://mirror.centos.org .

Now that you have your definition, you can modularize your samber-server.xml file to reuse its parts and version the distribution definition file components to make the build process more efficient and traceable. Part II explains this process.
